comments.commentBody: I  am starting my own vhs to digital conversion.  I started last summer compiling all the vhs movies.  Still not done with that but I have both a 6 yr old imac and a recently built custom PC.  I wanted to use my imac to convert but I figured it will not be up to the task.  I have looked into several analog to dv converters such as elgato, canopus (now grassvalley), and datavideo dac 200.  These all cost about 200 if you can find them used on Amazon.  I tried to use one of the cheaper alternatives but found there are software issues unlike with the ones I listed above which just allow you to convert just using imovie or movie maker and no other unnecessary software.  I really hope to get started on it soon before my tapes deteriorate.  You mention there are 40 analog to dv converters but are they any good? Thanks for this article, very helpful in my quest to complete my own video conversion project.
Editing family video is one hell of a chore, especially since it wont be appreciated for YEARS, but I edit a yearly video every december.
Garbage in, garbage forever.

The idea of archiving twitter messages is interesting though I don't agree that it necessarily challenges the elitism of history. It just adds another source. How we read it and what we challenge will partly depend on our own study of history.

The pioneering historian Ranajit Guha, in his article "Chandra's Death" takes a moment to reflect on "the small drama and fine detail of social existence" before using such detail to plunge ahead into a critical investigation of a murder of an ordinary woman in nineteenth century rural Bengal. Reading between and beyond court documents he finds what the court, mired as it was in the same patriarchy that resulted in the death, could not see. The woman who was found guilty at the time would never know that more than 100 years later, history cleared her name.

While twitter too records "the small drama and fine detail of social existence," it will take more than search engines to use this information to understand society or interpret history. It will require critical rigour, compassion, insight and "bending closer to the ground in order to pick up the traces," as Ranajit Guha has done to expose the systematic patriarchy that led to the death of one woman and the conviction of another woman for a crime committed by neither.

In closing, allow me to quote Ranajit Guha:

"The ordinary apparatus of historiography has little help to offer us here. Designed for big events and institutions, it is most at ease when made to operate on those larger phenomena which visibly stick out of the debris of the past. As a result, historical scholarship has developed, through recursive practice, a tradition that tends to ignore the small drama and fine detail of social existence, especially at its lower depths. A critical historiography can make up for this lacuna by bending closer to the ground in order to pick up the traces of a subaltern life in its passage through time."

from "Chandra's Death" in Subaltern Studies V, Writings on South Asian History and Society
Edited by Ranajit Guha
Delhi: Oxford University Press, 1987.
p. 138

(I hope that the comments on the New York Times are being archived as well.)

A Popular Mechanics article of a few years ago referred to the phenomenon of the Digital Ice Age for the relentless obsolescence of media and formats over time.

That's kind of hilarious that David got that call from Steve Jobs. Steve pretty well hit it on the head. Video is just so voluminous that it just sits there for years and years without getting looked at or edited.

Cheers to you David for finally getting a start with your project. Thanks for the interesting article.

When I converted my VHS tapes to digital - I new DVD's would become obsolete also- I also couldn't get my grown kids to sit down and watch the DVD's. So I'm uploaded them to YouTube. I will not have to worry about converting to a new technology - it's also a great back up. + my kids now watch them on their computers.

And what about all those AUDIO cassettes?? Long before we got a video camera we had a tape recorder, which documented family conversations and events for a couple of decades. It's the only source my grown children have to hear their dad's voice - he died of cancer when they were 3 and 6 - so very precious.

To Joon,

My apologies, Joon...! I quickly glanced at the constructor's name as I started and didn't catch that there was a co-constructor's name.....very sorry! and congratulations on a wonderful puzzle.

....gone to do 10 push ups.... : (

Let's see, when Israel does something bad, it is called defending the right fro Israel to exist. But, if the Muslim world does the exact same things Israel does; it is called terrorism. In my mind Israel is no different than Iran; neither state should have nuclear weapons and both states should be secular states. The leaders of both countries do not want peace, but want to destroy each other. Why should the United States be taking sides in this? Apparently, Americans ignore the fundamental reason fro 9/11; holding Israel to a different standard than the rest of the Islamic world. Mossad is as much of a terrorist organization as the Taliban, Humas and Al Queida.
Like her or not, the line about Obama "keeping the change" is a home run.
I like tea.  Let's have a tea party and invite the Mad Hatter.

I don't recall there being an article in the paper about Al Gore every single day for over a year after the election was stolen from him in 2000.  And yet we have to hear about this pretender every single day.  Why is the media making her relevant by reporting her activities?

To "gahanson" at post number 7:

"Estimates of the TEA Party event with Sarah Palin range from 10,000 to 16,000."

Um...no.

Under 3,000 is more like it.

The "orgsnizers" estimated than up to 10,000 people would show up.

10,000 did not show.

And the really swell thing--my fevered friend--there are photos of the crowd--taken from helicopters that eliminate the need to "estimate."

They can actually be counted.

As far as the size of the crowd of 1500 people that turned out for the Coakley event--in the dead of a Boston winter?

And the point there would be what?

That Coakley was lackluster, lame candidate who ran an uninspiring campaign?

Granted.

But if your point is Obama couldn't pull a crowd?

Please.

When Obama pulls big crowds (I've been in a few that measured tens thousands)--you folks on the right complain he's a rock star.

You folks really need to make up your minds.

Is he doing too much--or nothing?

Is he a socialist or a fascist?

A rock star playing to stadiumsor Maynard G. Krebs--sitting alone in his garage waiting for Dobie gillis to show up?

You can't have it both ways.

The Tax Policy Center estimate last June that 47% of all "tax units" would pay no Federal income tax in 2009.  It is difficult to complain your income tax is unfair when you don't pay any.  The Joint Committee on Taxation recently reported 27% of all tax returns filled for 2010 would have "negative tax liability", the government will be paying more money out to the taxpayer than is paid in.  Some of this is temporary, due to refundable tax credits included in the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act.

I like the sentiment, but this strikes me as grandstanding. Sanctions by the US alone will have little to no effect and they certainly won't be crippling. To deal with Iran we need to get a broad coalition on board. To me even the limited progress with China during the summit was a major advance on this front. We need to convince China and Russia that a radical Iranian government with nukes is a threat to them and to their interests.

So Congress wants to help. Great. But why send a public letter urging unilateral sanctions that won't be very effective? Make the point in private (as if the President didn't know this already). Let the administration work to build a coalition. It takes time but we've made progress. At the best this public letter doesn't do anything to negotiations with other countries but more likely it makes it more difficult for the administration to build a coalition (who wants to work with someone who already has decided what the end product must be, we may already know that, but lets not make it public).

So what does the letter do? It pins the administration in a corner. If it sensibly tries to build a coalition before taken action it is weak on Iran in our political discourse yet if it goes hawkish we end up with ineffective sanctions. But it is great for Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike. They can go back to their districts/states and argue they are leading the charge against the grave national security threat to the United States.

I didn't realize that somehow irresponsibility had become a constitutional requirement for service in the House or Senate.
Palin would be dangerous if she wasn't such a nitwit.

This is in response to comment 40. I notice how you use the term "they" to describe all of white middle class America, a group of human beings which for which you seem to feel very bitter towards. FYI, white middle class America, or whites in general, should be labeled any more than any other ethnic group in America. The government is still overwhelmingly white, even in congress. Everything that Obama has passed is passed because white people vote for it. When you call whites a "dying elite" it is both racist and ignorant.

As the late great Supreme Court Justice, Oliver Wendell Holmes, said (and I paraphrase), "taxes are the price we pay for a civilized society."

Apparently, the Tea Partiers do not want a civilized society. Too bad. Most of us do.
I thought Mitch and the GnOP Obstructionists cared about the economic plight of average Americans.

I get a big laugh out of the anti-Palin foamers, ranting about how dumb, fascist, and deluded she is. They are a far greater spectacle than she can hope to be, and this board is exhibit #1. If she is all that, what are you worried about? I like her. She's feisty, knows what's on most people's minds and is a whole lot more original than her lock-step right-thinking critics terrified of any dissent. I hope she keeps getting press so they lose sleep at night.
Don.... another word for Hutaree comes straight out of the demagogic dictionary.  Its origin is Creole.   The word is "bushwah".
The Tea Party: 18th century solutions to 21st century problems. No wonder the Chinese are eating our lunch.
They're worried about "taxation without representation?"  Two words for them:  Scott Brown.  But he didn't show up for their rally, did he?
Loopy? You betcha! But you have to give her credit for knowing how to cash in on her temporary (let's hope) fame.

@gahanson: It should be noted that when 0bama campaigned for Martha Coakley on the eve of the senate election in January, he drew only 1,500 in Boston. Estimates of the TEA Party event with Sarah Palin range from 10,000 to 16,000.

I was there at the Common this morning. On this very lovely spring day (not winter) the crowd was about 4,000, and about a third of it was there for curiosity or counter-protest. (Those opposed and supporting the Tea Party were intermingled; except for right near the podium, there was no clear gathering of people which only represented one view.)

The PA system was so terrible that only the few hundred closest to the speakers could hear. Thus it was an event tailored for TV and radio. The media cameras were all on the podium and I saw no cameras from the local news stations filming members of the crowd. While arguments took place between opposing attendees, it was pretty civilized, although the pro-Palins had very few facts at their command, mostly just insults.
